Operation 'AddIpToAllowList' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Description lacks clarity about what is returned (response structure) and the immediate side effect of allowing access. Added information about return values (IDs and timestamps) and the side effect that access is immediately granted. This helps AI agents understand the full impact of the operation.

data.current_summary: Add one or more IPs to the allow list
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to add one or more allowed IP addresses.**

To allow one or more IP addresses, pass them to this endpoint in an array. Once an IP address is added to your allow list, it will be assigned an `id` that can be used to remove the address. You can retrieve the ID associated with an IP using the "Retrieve a list of currently allowed IPs" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: This endpoint allows you to add one or more IP addresses to your allow list. Pass IP addresses in an array format. Each added IP address will be assigned a unique `id` for future reference and removal. Returns the created IP address entries with their assigned IDs and timestamps. Once added, these IPs will immediately be allowed to access your account through the UI or API.
data.reasoning: Description lacks clarity about what is returned (response structure) and the immediate side effect of allowing access. Added information about return values (IDs and timestamps) and the side effect that access is immediately granted. This helps AI agents understand the full impact of the operation.

message: Operation 'DeleteAllowedIps' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Description lacks explicit information about what is returned and emphasizes the critical side effect (self-blocking) but could be clearer about the immediate consequence. Restructured to highlight the critical warning more prominently and added explicit mention of return value confirmation. This helps AI agents understand the severity of potential mistakes and the operation's full impact.

data.current_summary: Remove one or more IPs from the allow list
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to remove one or more IP addresses from your list of allowed addresses.**

To remove one or more IP addresses, pass this endpoint an array containing the ID(s) associated with the IP(s) you intend to remove. You can retrieve the IDs associated with your allowed IP addresses using the "Retrieve a list of currently allowed IPs" endpoint.

It is possible to remove your own IP address, which will block access to your account. You will need to submit a [support ticket](https://sendgrid.com/docs/ui/account-and-settings/support/) if this happens. For this reason, it is important to double check that you are removing only the IPs you intend to remove when using this endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: This endpoint allows you to remove one or more IP addresses from your allow list by passing an array of IP IDs. Returns confirmation of removed IPs. **Critical:** Removing your own IP address will immediately block your account access. Verify you are only removing intended IPs before submission. If you accidentally remove your own IP, contact support for account recovery. You can retrieve IP IDs using the "Retrieve a list of currently allowed IPs" endpoint.
data.reasoning: Description lacks explicit information about what is returned and emphasizes the critical side effect (self-blocking) but could be clearer about the immediate consequence. Restructured to highlight the critical warning more prominently and added explicit mention of return value confirmation. This helps AI agents understand the severity of potential mistakes and the operation's full impact.

message: Operation 'GetAllowedIp' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_output_details. Description contains a typo ('retreive') and lacks specificity about what data is returned. Added explicit information about the response structure (id, ip, timestamps) and clarified the path parameter requirement. This improves clarity for AI agents to understand the operation's inputs and outputs.

data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to retreive a specific IP address that has been allowed to access your account.**

You must include the ID for the specific IP address you want to retrieve in your call. You can retrieve the IDs associated with your allowed IP addresses using the "Retrieve a  list of currently allowed IPs" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: This endpoint retrieves details for a specific allowed IP address by its ID. Requires the IP rule ID as a path parameter. Returns the IP address entry with its `id`, `ip` value, `created_at`, and `updated_at` timestamps. Use the "Retrieve a list of currently allowed IPs" endpoint to obtain the rule ID if needed.
data.reasoning: Description contains a typo ('retreive') and lacks specificity about what data is returned. Added explicit information about the response structure (id, ip, timestamps) and clarified the path parameter requirement. This improves clarity for AI agents to understand the operation's inputs and outputs.

data.current_summary: Remove a specific IP from the allowed list
data.current_description:
**This endpoint allows you to remove a specific IP address from your list of allowed addresses.**

When removing a specific IP address from your list, you must include the ID in your call.  You can retrieve the IDs associated with your allowed IP addresses using the "Retrieve a list of currently allowed IPs" endpoint.
data.description_suggestion: This endpoint removes a specific IP address from your allow list using its rule ID as a path parameter. Returns a success confirmation. The removed IP will immediately lose access to your account through the UI and API. Exercise caution to avoid removing your own IP address, which would block your account access. Contact support if you accidentally remove your own IP.
data.reasoning: Description lacks information about the response and the immediate side effect of access revocation. Added explicit details about return value, the immediate consequence of removal, and a warning about self-blocking similar to the batch delete operation. This ensures consistency across related operations and helps AI agents understand the full impact.
